job_title: Social Media Strategist in New York, NY
pros:
Incredible benefits and unionized for non-managers. Outside of the regular medical/dental/vision, they offer pre-tax metrocards, flexible spending for medical costs, pension (vested at 3 yrs), and an employee assistance program to help with any kind of personal wellbeing, financial or emotional problem for you and your family/friends. Plus other small perks like a discounted exercise class, subsidized lunch program, and fun programs for staff (with food).

The benefits alone make UJA an incredible place to work, but it's also a caring and friendly environment.
cons:
Although the office operates on a hybrid schedule post covid shutdown, there isn't flexibility to work remotely full-time, or to choose which days you come in vs. stay home.

Some people easily find opportunities for advancement, other do not.

pros: Lot of great people there doing good work
cons: Didn't love commute bc of how far I lived at time

pros: I found working at UJA to be pretty fulfilling work because I believe in the mission. Most of the volunteers were kind. The office was centrally located and the work-life balance was good for junior employees, though I often saw senior staff working long hours.
cons: The atmosphere was a little cliquey, and not everyone was welcoming. There was little room for advancement to new roles.

pros:
- nice office
- frequently free food
- good healthcare benefits
- office is closed most Jewish holidays and closes early on Fridays in winter
- working for a good cause
cons:
Poor management. Most mid-senior to senior management have been with the organization for decades. There is a lot of bad behavior and poor leadership that goes unchecked. 

HR not responsive... uncomfortable for employees to come forth with issues, so things fester and just stay status quo. And they will lowball you on salary negotiations.

Negative culture and office environment. Generally unfriendly and cliquey. No "water cooler" talk. 

No clear path for career advancement. Mid-senior and senior folks hold onto their jobs for decades, so everyone below is just stuck in their role. There is very little professional development. 

** Disclaimer:  there are some great leaders and managers in the organization. These "rockstars" are loved by their teams and respected by  other employees. But there are far too few of these people. **

review_title: If you enjoy innovation, don't work here.
pros:
- Some incredible colleagues
- Decent work/life balance
- Solid benefits
cons:
UJA is a place where people go to either: a) start their careers and stay a year or two, or b) stay for 35+ years while raising children and either retire or be discharged unceremoniously. It's a place that allows you to have a life, which is of great import to many, but everything you do is very cut-and-dried. 

I had two different types of tasks at UJA: easy and frustrating. The frustration was always caused by a hierarchical structure which condoned petulant behavior and consistently treated certain departments as support staff unworthy of the same respect as others. 

Attempts to change the status quo are not condoned; in fact, they are immediately quashed by senior staff who want to do the least amount of work possible and have zero interest in developing employees. There are few to no opportunities for growth and the most valued trait in an employee is the ability to shut up and smile.

I say this not because I am in any way disgruntled; this type of structure works really well for many, many people. I'm saying it as a cautionary tale against people who believe that UJA is a place where they can advance their career or explore new opportunities. It is not, and if you seek that, please look elsewhere.

review_title: The best nonprofit to learn from

pros: Amazing atmosphere, great staff and benefits

pros: Nice office. Some good people.
cons: UJA exists to keep top management employed. Everyone else is expendable.

review_title: Caring Mission, But Only Outside The Office
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Early Fridays if you can take advantage.
cons: Too many layers of management, workers below stretched to the max for mediocre compensation. Just because it's a nonprofit shouldn't mean that the workers who propel it should be bled dry.  There are some nice people but crazy workloads drive everyone over the edge. There's no relief, no improvement. Not enough hiring that would alleviate some of the stress in the trenches. HR is a joke, big topic of discussion. Don't expect any help there. Too many people have been part of the problem, not the solution for too many years, which has caused stagnation and a treading water  mentality instead of a solving problems mentality.  Just a place to get in some time practicing your skills and then start looking. Don't worry, all the lifers will be there if you decide to come back, so you won't have to make new friends.

job_title: Founder &Amp; Chief Executive Officer in Toronto, ON
pros: Great cause, smart staff, meaningful work
cons: Nonprofit sector can be challenging.

review_title: Read and consider carefully before accepting a opportunity  at UJA
job_title: Operations Production & Reporting (OPR) Representative in New York, NY
pros: Time off, Jewish Holidays off and paid vacation and sick time.
cons: UJA may seem like a great place to work, due to its image and the things they do for the community, however UJA does not pay fair, nor do they recognize employee growth. Came in with a G.E.D, earn my associates and bachelors degree, however the 7 years I been working at UJA it seems that the only candidates that are eligible for growth are of a specific ethnic. So if you are a minority, color person please consider that if you agree to a job at UJA most likely it will be on the position you will be working in.  Once I started working and saw this place as a place of growth and success, I failed to realize the truth, the ratio of minority working are only fulfilling UJA duties of hiring non Jews. For 7 years I choose not to believe this, until I try every door and each door was closed, im stating this because I'm one of the few that have seek for a higher education in thinking that being better equipped with skills set would excel me, however the truth lies when you working here. Don't let the image fool you.

pros: If you despise change, high quality work, and have an affinity to office politics this is the place for you! If not, at least there's a good deal of PTO.
cons:
UJA is an organization that is stuck in its ways, often forgetting that it is the 21st century. Decisions are made very slowly if at all, change is non-existent, and technology is under-utilized. People there are cliquey and like to play office politics. Many of those in senior positions are there through connections and other means not reflective of their skills. Some that have been there for decades are utterly incompetent.

Hard work is rarely recognized and is rewarded even less often. Work/life balance is poor because rather than replacing staff that leaves, others are given more responsibilities with no change in title or pay.

review_title: Great place to work... if you're in the 1%.
pros: Jewish and national holidays off. Generous vacation and sick policy. Overall, employees are friendly. Very nice office space, updated and clean facilities. Great location.
cons: Very top-heavy organization, extremely bureaucratic environment. Very easy to get ahead if you're from a wealthy family who can buy your way through the organization by making donations and connections. Promotions awarded based on connections and on a "who's-who" basis, rather than on merit. Organization encourages mediocrity by not awarding staff with raises, title changes or bonuses. Staff are expected to work late night and weekend events and are not compensated for overtime.

review_title: UJA-Federation was a great place to work!
pros: The leadership was engaged, inspiring and fair.  Although salary wasn't great, we had a lot of time off for Jewish holidays (which is a real benefit if you're not very religious), at the director level had a good amount of vacation, and had a pension.  I found the environment to be a great as people were passionate about their work and we could see the impact we had on the community. Good work/life balance.
cons: Salary was not great.  At the director level (mid-management) there wasn't much opportunity for mobility.  The organization is bureaucratic and it can take a long time for change to occur.

pros: Contribute your support for others in need
cons: Rigid, machine-like structure to organization, which prevents employees from utilizing multiple skills they may have to better accomplish goals. Does not treat employees nearly as well as they treat the donors or groups/organizations that are its beneficiaries. Major salary discrepancies. CEO makes way too much for a philanthropic organization- over half a million dollars. Others are struggling. Should be an embarrassment to everyone involved in those decisions.

review_title: They do great work, but it's not great to work there
pros:
As an organization, UJA does incredible work. They are the largest local philanthropy in the world, and as such are capable of responding to challenges in ways other nonprofits cannot. 

They promote from within where appropriate. They offer a variety of professional development courses. They have a generous vacation policy and offer other non-financial benefits.
cons: There is a pervasive culture of fear and disrespect. Compensation is below market rate. Performance reviews are down only. Workloads are egregious. The staff does not grow in proportion to the organization's impact in the community. Promotions are a doubling of workload, not a change in responsibilities.

pros:
Great, talented people
A very open work atmosphere
The sense that you are helping people in need
cons:
Changes not communicated efficiently
A lot of good ideas but poor implementation
Leadership not interested in investing in talent
No work/life balance - you will work way beyond the prescribed hours

pros: A stable, healthy place to work.  Good job to have if your partner makes more money than you do...benefits, vacation, holidays, flexible work schedule, etc.
cons: This org is penny-wise and pound foolish. They seem to do everything they can to retain except for monetary compensation.  They are not allowing for any title changes or advancements in order to quash any and all requests for increase of salary.  They lose more money through lost productivity than they save in low salaries...at-least that is the case with me.

pros: This non-profit is more corporate, given its size and dollars raised, which is nice because there's such a large community. They celebrate the holidays with all staff conferences, they offer ample opportunities for professional development, and there are always bagels around(!). It's really nice to come to work every day with a mission and know you're serving both the Jewish community and larger NYC community. Everyone for the most part is really friendly and willing to help you out if you need it. It's nice to have all departments in-office, so you can focus on what you need to get done (for example if you're in development, there are the in-house marketing, events, etc teams to assist you in what you need to get done).
cons: Office drama/politics really depends on your team/smaller division, some have a lot and others have none. It's very rare for an assistant to be promoted, which is such a shame to the organization. Why wouldn't you promote the people who have put in time and are the backbone of the organization? It's unrealistic to expect recent college grads from top schools to work as an admin more than a year. That point becomes especially frustrating when outsiders are hired for positions they aren't qualified for and make much higher salaries. It's interesting how the budget is created for each team, which makes you wonder why some areas get very little and others should have the fat trimmed... The last con is how events aren't fairly distributed between staff- there are some who work almost every event and others who work none. The organization survives only on the amount of dollars raised, so it's everyone's job to pitch in every now and then, whether or not you're on the fundraising side of the company or senior staff.

review_title: Great place to work; hard to advance
pros: UJA is a great organization to work for. They treat their employees well and there are lots of benefits offered. They understand people have families and have flexible working schedules and offer lots of sick days to help when life gets in the way of things.
cons: There is not a lot of room for advancement in the organization. Many of the top positions are filled for the long term and people in those roles do not transition over, leaving a frozen ladder.

pros: Amazing work-life balance - vacation, holidays and early shabbat closing. Great mission for people to be inspired by.
cons: Operates as a big bureaucracy even though the company is not that big. Lack of leadership vision and clarity in direction. Lack of purposeful career development and investment in employees.

pros: Many days off for Jewish holidays, decent amount of paid time off.
cons: Very low pay and no opportunities for advancement. Responsibilities are frequently growing, while salaries and titles do not. Misguided executive team that lacks vision for long-term growth. Poor use of technology leads to many missed opportunities. Despite frequent talk of changing with the times, the general mentality is things are done a certain way because that is how they were always done in the past and how they will continue to be in the future.

pros: Relatively good benefits plan. Early dismissal for Shabbat.
cons: Lots of meetings, decisions by group-think, difficulty instilling new ideas or ways of doing things, lots of competition and sniping at the top echelons. Relatively low salaries at all but the top levels - perhaps to encourage or as a recognition that most lower level employees will only stay a couple of years.

review_title: For people looking for a career in fundraising at a Jewish non-profit, this is the place
pros: UJA-Federation is a great place to work, provided you know what you're getting into. Lately, the organization has been hiring lots of talented, professional, and sometimes overqualified staff, many from Ivy League schools. This is beneficial for the institutional culture, which is very friendly, collaborative, and mostly easygoing. People coming as low-level fundraisers or commission workers have a near-automatic opportunity to be promoted, as there's a clear hierarchy for that and time spent on the job becomes synonymous with experience. Most employees are very attentive about the 35-hour work week rule, especially union members, so you'll see a lot of people coming in at 9 sharp and dashing out the door at 4:50 pm. The prestige of UJA is hard to over-estimate. I think it's pretty easy to get hired at most other Jewish non-profits with UJA on your resume.
cons:
First of all, if you are hoping for a high-paying job at UJA just because it seems more corporate than most NPOs, DO NOT WASTE YOUR TIME. The compensation structure here is preposterous, and union meetings can get pretty out of hand. The executives here are making mid-six figure salaries while entry-level staff are barely making a minimum wage for New York City. There's an implicit assumption that new hires have their parents to fall back on financially, as it's next to impossible to get by on $35k per year on your own. 

Second, UJA suffers from an extremely conservative approach and an overloaded board of directors, plain and simple. This is because UJA basically stands for "establishment" in most people's minds. Outreach to young people is poor, and the most effective arm of that seems to be children of major donors. UJA's presence is not exactly "cool and hip;" its target demographic is basically old high net-worth Jews, and the annual campaign does well when those donors are making money in the stock market. As others have mentioned, this is not a place where you come in and start making waves and changing things around. Almost all power is consolidated at the top and everyone else is left to essentially follow their job descriptions. 

Finally, like many other Jewish non-profits, there is a HUGE gender gap here. Women outnumber men maybe 7-to-1. Ethnic diversity is very low, as would be expected. Unfortunately, many employees fall into the old stereotypes: clique-y, loud, consumerist, and obsessed with where you can find the best low-calorie salad in the area. Men, proceed with caution.

review_title: Very well rounded organization that prides itself on being a great place to work.
pros: Working to further the mission of the organization that helps communities in NY and around the world. The atmosphere of the organization is high spirited and calm. There are great growth opportunities in fundraising and programming and the management is lovely. People have been with the organization for 30 years, proving that people love working for this great organization.
cons: As this is a non-profit, salaries aren't going to match the for profit companies. Also, you must push yourself to move up this ladder.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Fun environment full of other recent grads. Lots of days off for religious holidays, enriching community. Really offers a great life style and name recognition of the organization.
cons: Most people care about the cause but the environment is immature and cliquey. It felt like a lot of young people are they because its an easy paycheck, not because they're looking to excel or work hard. Pay is low. Inefficient systems. Personalities run the show without regard for effective management

review_title: The work was good. The supervision was not
pros: Doing good for people is a big plus.  Gaining fundraising experience for a national organization is also a plus.  There are opportunities to learn and get involved.  Also an opportunity to learn about a fundraising platform.
cons: Poor management and not that much opportunity for creativity or expansion.   Not a lot of out of the box kind of thinking.  Very top heavy in management with folks who have been there for ever.

pros: There is a young workforce here, and so the energy is fun.  I worked in a call room environment, so work went by fast because you were always speaking to someone new.
cons: Management of the call center was young with poor oversight.  Turnover in the fundraising call center was great, for that reason.

review_title: Not as professional as you would imagine
pros: Employees really care about the cause; employees are quite nice to those in their department; the environment is flexible; the work isn't hard so most employees don't have 40 hours of work/week leading to a very social culture
cons: The CPAR (non-fundraising) departments lack strategy or processes to decide when and how to pursue work. In addition, the leadership (Managing Directors and Executive Directors as well as their bosses) don't have the professional expertise or experience to be leading their employees.

review_title: Management is out of touch and has their heads buried in the sand
pros: Does terrific work and has a great reputation and very established. Competitive salary for senior management and good benefits.
cons: Terrible office politics and dysfunctional in certain departments. Employees at the mid-level are not treated well. Senior management does not engage the employee base and is unaware of what goes on within the departments. Not a progressive and employee friendly organization.

job_title: Marketing Director in New York, NY
pros: The organization helps New Yorkers in need regardless of background/religion/ethnicity, as well as jews all over the world.
cons: People internally don't necessarily treat each other nicely. You would think that all working for a common good would make it a great working environment. Not when your boss is psycho, everyone knows it and no one does anything about it.

pros:
Good exposure
Great people
Flexible hours

It was a great place to work if you are looking for a soft landing in new york. If you are looking to advance your business career I would say look elsewhere.
cons:
No learning of hard skills
Not many projects

They did not understand how valuable I was as an intern and did not make use of me.

job_title: Planning Professional in New York, NY
pros: Religious Jewish environment where a staff rabbi gives sermons on Jewish holidays and at staff meetings.
cons: You will fail at your job here because leadership has no vision or plan and very little qualifications for their jobs. You will not be set up to succeed and will take the fall because leadership will never admit that they are failing at their roles. Staff moral is extremely low and there are lots of job openings because people do not stay here long, people are constantly quitting. Save yourself the pain and suffering and trust all the negative reviews of this horrible place.

pros:
Smart colleagues.  
Nice office space
In house caterer makes great cookies.
cons:
2018 reorganization led to widespread unhappiness which management has done little to address.
Old school hierarchical structure — despite giving lip service to new models.
Culture of favoritism. Little room to advance if you are not buddies with your boss.
Senior leadership does not articulate a vision for organization 
Culture of disrespect among staff at odds with Jewish values

review_title: Corrupt and unhealthy place to work or give money to
pros: Large organization with lots of resources
cons: Terrible senior staff and HR who throw staff under the bus and negatively talk about donors behind their backs. It is a toxic environment that pits people against each other for personal gain instead of spending dollars actually making measurable impacts in the community or investing in employees. Organization takes credit for every agency even if UJA-Federation is a tiny part of an agency's budget.

pros: UJA is Family Friendly organization.  Reasonably good health and vacation benefits.  Overall the people are warm and friendly.
cons: Limited career paths, lots of employee turnover at entry and midlevel.  Union is a big deterrent and salary compensation is poor.

review_title: Considering employment here, think twice.  UJA is a pool of mediocrity.  The pay is extremely low and no raises.
job_title: In the Marketing Department in New York, NY
pros: The benefits are excellent, and it CAN be a good training ground.  But get your teeth cut then move on.
cons: Very low pay with no raises, some of the rudest people I have ever had the displeasure of working with.  I thought it was me but I started a new job a few months ago, and it's worlds different.

pros: Creating positive impact on community, diverse work environment, closed all Jewish holidays, takes interest in training employees
cons: very bureaucratic, nepotistic, adverse to change, salaries are low compared to other large non-profits, sometimes too large for it's own good

review_title: UJA takes care of the world but doesn't do a good job of taking care of it's employees
pros: It's wonderful to work for an organization that improves the lives of millions of people around the world. The staff is very dedicated and committed to their jobs.  I've been privileged  to work with some extremely bright and talented lay leaders as well as professionals.
cons: Management is comprised of either social workers or people who are not trained to be effective managers. Their is  so much that we are expected to accomplish that it is impossible to follow-up in a meaningful way before having to move on the the next project. We are pulled in so many different directions, the stress level is exceedingly high, expectations are very high, and  poor managers often impede our ability to be more successful. Managers fail to recognition work that is well done but they never fail to criticize minutia. All but  upper management is underpaid and overworked.Young employees are forced to leave the organization for both professional advancement and financial opportunities. Older employees have limited ability to be upwardly mobile or financial rewarded for years of hard work, dedication and commitment to the organization.

pros: This is an organization that understands that work doesn't always come first.  The vacation and sick days are generous and supervisors are, for the most part, very understanding.
cons: Like working for any other non-profit, the work load can sometimes be daunting.  There is always a certain level of pressure to complete several assignments at once.

review_title: It's a good place to start your career.
job_title: Program Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: The diverse staff, knowledge of the good work done, feeling that your work makes a difference, and ability to meet and network with other colleagues
cons: Uneven promotions, organization is very bureaucratic, progress is slow.

review_title: Experience at UJA-Federation of New York
pros: Very regular hours, off for all Jewish holidays, lots of friendly people, and the building is very nice and subway-accessible.
cons: There seem to be few opportunities for upward mobility, management isn't always the most helpful resource if you have a question, and it isn't run in the most efficient way possible.

pros: There is staff comradery, good health benefits, professional development opportunities, higher education degrees are encouraged, and the staff has diverse backgrounds.
cons: The organization tends to require a lot of time from their staff which leads to working longer hours than the average non-profit and the salaries aren't always competitive with the non-profit market.

pros: Great Benefits and a great training program for fundraising
cons: Doesn't allow for professional growth. The supervisors are often old and stuck in their ways, not interested in innovation. There is also a racist undertone to work environment.

review_title: Very bureaucratic for a good cause
pros: Doing good walk for a great cause and result. Why you are doing the job and good colleagues are the reward.
cons: Very political atmosphere and limited opportunity to advance for most.

pros: UJA federation of new york is a learning environment as it offers its employees opportunities to receive on the job training in its application systems usage, soft skills etc
cons: uja federation has limited advancement, it needs to have other opportunities for its emplyees otherwise it will be a revolving door

pros: UJA supports amazing work! Great benefits, especially coming back from maternity leave. Casual dress code. Generous holidays off.
cons: Reviews are meaningless and merit is not often recognized. Low base pay and little room for salary increases, little formal mentorship or any sort of development for general skills. Culture can be tense and nasty.

review_title: enjoyed working with colleagues who taught me a lot and working for an organization that does so much good for the world
job_title: Development Associate in New York, NY
pros: good mentorship, days off for Jewish holidays, casual work environment, good hours(usually)
cons: not a lot of room for growth, can have mixed messaging in regards to promotions and how to advance

job_title: Planning Director in New York, NY
pros: ok benefits, central location in new york
cons: completely not innovative, antiquated way of doing things, doesn't value new way of making their work relevant to diverse demographics

pros: Learn a a lot in a very short period. Good if you have no family.
cons: Lots of extra hours,  no work / life balance. Supervisors very critical and fast to "pass the blame" when something goes wrong.

pros: I really enjoyed working at UJA-Federation, mostly because of my wonderful head of division. There was also a real sense of work/life balance that is hard to find.
cons: There was a change in leadership at the highest levels which led to some confusion in direction of the organization.

pros: Level Headed Management, strong leadership, good training for entry level professionals and great communication.
cons: Some times things can get complicated because of the size but all in all things can get done.  Not to much room for quick advancement

job_title: Development Assistant in New York, NY
pros: organization does a lot of good, senior staff is supportive, strong leadership, work/life balance
cons:
super bureaucratic
lower-level staff doesn't have much input
some people are stretched too thin
not necessarily a lot of room for growth
people in high-up positions tend to stay there

pros: Great place - extremely professional while also friendly atmosphere.
cons: The federation is extremely large and therefore its easy to get lost in the crowd. If you're the kind of person to get lost in a big pond, consider that.

review_title: Great Place to Launch Your Career
pros: Lots of exposure to a wide variety of sectors, tons of days off and an effort to establish a caring community
cons: top heavy and difficult to navigate the politics

review_title: This company is not very inclusive of all people.  They prefer their own and only promote their own.
